case_title: MUSLIM COMMERCIAL BANK LTD. through General Manager Circle Office, Peshawar vs SHAMSUL AULIA
appellant: Muslim Commercial Bank Ltd. through General Manager Circle Office, Peshawar

accussed_details.name: Shamsul Aulia
allegation: Failure to inform management about misappropriation
Violation of bank staff rules by not obtaining presenter’s signature on cheques

accussed_details.name: Attaullah
allegation: Direct misappropriation of Rs. 11,82,300 through 31 cheques

facts.grievance_petition: Filed by Shamsul Aulia, Ex. Officer Grade III, MCB Bisham, District Shangla.
facts.main_charge: Misappropriation by Manager Attaullah; respondent alleged to have concealed the fact and violated bank rules.

complaint_summary: The respondent, Shamsul Aulia, was accused of facilitating misappropriation of Rs. 11,82,300 by failing to follow bank rules, specifically by not obtaining the presenter’s signature on cheques. The main charge of misappropriation was against the Manager, Attaullah.
investigation_summary: Separate inquiries were conducted for Attaullah and Shamsul Aulia. Attaullah admitted misappropriation and repaid the amount, abandoning legal remedies. The Labour Court initially dismissed the petitions, but the Labour Appellate Tribunal remanded the cases for determination of maintainability. Eventually, the Labour Court reinstated Shamsul Aulia with full back-benefits.

legal_proceedings.labour_court_decision: Grievance petition accepted; dismissal order set aside; reinstated with full back-benefits.
legal_proceedings.cross_objection: Filed by respondent questioning inquiry findings but no further relief claimed.

appeal_history.tribunal_decision: Employees declared workmen; cases remanded to Labour Court for merits.

appeal_history.manager_action: Attaullah deposited misappropriated amount and abandoned legal remedy.

judgment_summary: The court upheld the Labour Court’s decision to reinstate Shamsul Aulia, finding that the allegations against him were based on conjecture rather than evidence. The bank failed to prove that his actions facilitated misappropriation. The appeal and cross-objection were dismissed.
Decision_or_verdict: Appeal dismissed; reinstatement of respondent upheld.

final_decision.reasoning: Bank failed to establish connection between rule violation and misappropriation facilitation.

legal_arguments: Prosecution argued that failure to follow bank rules facilitated misappropriation.
Defense argued that mere violation of rules does not constitute misconduct and cited relevant precedents.

contentions: Respondent facilitated misappropriation by failing to obtain presenter’s signature on cheques.
Payments made without verifying identity of presenter.
Inquiry findings on misconduct should not be interfered unless perverse or illegal.
references: Raja Javed Akhtar v. Executive Vice-President UBL (1998 SCMR 212)
Muhammad Shamim v. Pakistan Tobacco Company (1975 SCMR 46)

contentions: No allegation of misappropriation against respondent.
Manager Attaullah accepted sole responsibility for misappropriation.
Failure to follow rules does not per se amount to misconduct.
references: Allied Bank of Pakistan v. M. Zaheerul Hassan (1990 PLC 238)
Cresent Jute Products Ltd. v. Muhammad Yaqub etc. (PLD 1978 SC 207)

key_points: No evidence respondent was aware of misappropriation.
Inquiry Officer’s findings based on conjecture, not evidence.
Bank failed to prove how failure to obtain signature facilitated misappropriation.
precedents: Cresent Jute Products Ltd. case allows Labour Court to determine facts.
Muhammad Shamim case limits Labour Court’s review to legality of procedure.

citations: Raja Javed Akhtar v. Executive Vice-President UBL (1998 SCMR 212)
Muhammad Shamim v. Pakistan Tobacco Company (1975 SCMR 46)
Allied Bank of Pakistan v. M. Zaheerul Hassan (1990 PLC 238)
Cresent Jute Products Ltd. v. Muhammad Yaqub (PLD 1978 SC 207)

witness_statement.Shamsul Aulia: Denied knowledge of misappropriation and clarified actions regarding cheque payments.

key_issues: Whether failure to follow bank rules constitutes misconduct.
Extent of Labour Court’s jurisdiction to examine factual findings.

maxims.Double Check Principle: Labour Court has full authority to re-examine facts regardless of domestic inquiry findings.

legal_terms.Misconduct: Violation of established rules or procedures without evidence of intent to facilitate wrongdoing.

words_and_phrases.Facilitation: Actions or omissions that indirectly enable wrongdoing.

summary_vector_notes: The case revolves around allegations of misconduct against a cashier for failing to follow bank rules, which allegedly facilitated misappropriation by the branch manager. The court dismissed the appeal, emphasizing lack of evidence and conjectural findings by the Inquiry Officer.
